A Practical Guide to Antibiotics

Published on January 25, 2025 | By JW

Antibiotics are one of the few domains over which the general internist still commands jurisdiction. In medical school, I was drawn to microbiology/antibiotics thanks to Sketchy. I have found that medical students and interns alike often feel hesitation with antibiotic selection, borne at least in part out of learning several dozen microbes and their pharmacological counterparts and their mechanisms of actions in the classroom in a haphazard manner, and in part out of a habit of using a specific but seemingly arbitrary set of antibiotics on the wards that depends highly on institutional habits but devoid of any sensible structure. Here I’ll share a simplified but practically high-yield framework for thinking about antibiotics in the inpatient setting. As an early trainee, you will immediately add value to many medicine teams and most non-medicine teams (I’m looking at you, surgery, AKA the Ancef aficionados) by wielding your antibiotic scepter with confidence.

As always, be familiar with your institutional practices, stay up to date with your local antibiogram trends, and keep your pharmacy and ID colleagues close. Use nuance, of which the approach described herein lacks, when making clinical decisions.

Bacterial Classifications

Roughly, we will approach different clinical classes of bacteria as follows:

  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA): ***

  • Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs): ***
  • Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE): ***
